subject: Re: [junit] test protected method outside package
msgSnippet: Actually, I see protected methods as a public API restricted to subclasses--anyone can get at the method if they re willing to work hard enough.  It s similar
messageBody:
Actually, I see protected methods as a public API restricted to
subclasses--anyone can get at the method if they're willing to work hard
enough. It's similar to a public instance method on a class with a
private constructor--for some reason, there are hoops that the client
needs to jump through to get at that method.

The proper way to test such a method is to extend MyClass. JUnit 4
makes this easier, because your test class can directly extend MyClass.
However, this test may feel a bit awkward, which might lead you to think
about other ways of structuring your code. Lately, I find that my
protected methods are more likely to be abstract in the superclass,
allowing the superclass to call down into the subclass, rather than
accessors in the superclass intended to be called up from subclasses.
It's the Hollywood principle ("Don't call me, I'll call you") applied to
object hierarchies.

David Saff

Stephen Smith wrote:
> Hi Kamal,
>
> This can be achieved in a number of ways. The simplest option is to
> extend org.apache.net.MyClass and over-ride the protected method, but
> that's not a terribly clean solution. If you want to test a method and
> its protected, are you sure it shouldn't be public? This sounds like a
> bit of a TDD design smell to me.
>
> Steve.
> --
> Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
> http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/
>
> Kamal Ahmed wrote:
> > Hi,
> >
> >
> >
> > Does any one know how I can test protected method outside a package?
> Without
> > moving the test class into the package where the method to be tested
> > resides.
> >
> >
> >
> > Method to be tested = methodA()
> >
> > Package = org.apache.net
> >
> >
> >
> > Test Method = testMethodA()
> >
> > Package = org.apache.net.test.unit
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > -Kamal.
> >
> >
> >
> > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
> >
> >
